references:
Inspired by [31], we also explore the progressive training approach for federated multimodal learning, denoted as Prog-FedMML.
Progressive training, as demonstrated in [31] and [32], has the potential to outperform end-to-end training.
Similar to the layer-wise approach, progressive training begins with an initial encoder F𝐹F without any layers. A new layer Lssuperscript𝐿𝑠L^{s} is sequentially added at each stage s𝑠s.
However, unlike the layer-wise approach, all existing layers in F𝐹F are trained during each stage s𝑠s.
Specifically for multimodal learning, Prog-FedMML trains layers [La1,…,Las]superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑎1…superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑎𝑠[L_{a}^{1},\dots,L_{a}^{s}], and [Lb1,…,Lbs]superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑏1…superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑏𝑠[L_{b}^{1},\dots,L_{b}^{s}] within encoders Fasubscript𝐹𝑎F_{a} and Fbsubscript𝐹𝑏F_{b} during stage s𝑠s.
As a result, Prog-FedMML is more resource-intensive than LW-FedMML,
as it requires training all layers added in prior stages, rather than freezing them.
The computational and communication resource requirements of Prog-FedMML for an FL training round gradually increase and eventually match those of end-to-end training by the final stage (i.e., s=S𝑠𝑆s=S).
This similarity in resource demands can lead to the same drawbacks as end-to-end training, particularly in excluding clients with limited resources from the FL process, thereby losing valuable data for model training.
We compare the different characteristics of conventional end-to-end, progressive, and layer-wise training approaches for an encoder F𝐹F in Table I, highlighting how the layers are managed and utilized at each stage.

S4.T2.caption: TABLE II: Distribution of FL communication rounds for each stage of layer-wise training on the COCO dataset.

LW-FedMML 15 15 15 15 15 15 90 21.26 48.54 62.21 89.30 30.48 59.32 71.58 92.50
LW-FedMML 0 0 0 10 30 50 90 25.22 53.82 66.92 91.30 35.52 65.78 76.88 94.20
references:
Given a limited number of FL rounds (i.e., R=90𝑅90R=90), we first determine how to allocate them to different stages for layer-wise training.
As shown in Table II, we experiment with two strategies: uniformly distributing the FL rounds across all stages and allocating more rounds to the later stages.
Prior work [32] indicates that allocating the FL rounds uniformly or more to earlier stages is effective in the absence of pre-trained weights.
However, our findings in Table II demonstrate that allocating more rounds to the later stages achieves superior performance compared to uniform distribution when using pretrained weights.
Therefore, we adopt this allocation strategy in our subsequent experiments.
For Prog-FedMML, we use uniform allocation unless otherwise stated.

For the ADVANCE dataset, we allocate FL rounds to later stages for Prog-FedMML, as we do for LW-FedMML in Table II.
Table VI compares the performance of different approaches and relative resource requirements for a single client.
The measurement of resource requirements follows the same approach as in the instance discrimination-based setting.
The table shows that Prog-FedMML achieves the best performance, while LW-FedMML maintains competitive performance across various metrics compared to FedMML in a supervised multimodal learning setting.
In Fig. 9, we can observe that LW-FedMML significantly lowers the resource requirements compared to FedMML, while Prog-FedMML exhibits similar resource demands as FedMML.

S4.T3.caption: TABLE III: Learning rate for encoders of different modalities.
S4.T3.table:
Dataset Modality Stage s𝑠\boldsymbol{s}

references:
We uniformly split the data among the clients for the COCO dataset.
We set the batch size to 256 and use τ=0.05𝜏0.05\tau=0.05 in Eq. 3.
For LW-FedMML and Prog-FedMML, we use the learning rates shown in Table III for the image and text encoders at each stage.
The learning rate for the projection heads of both modalities is set to 3e-4.
For the conventional end-to-end FedMML, the learning rates for the image and text encoders are set to 1e-7 and 1e-5, respectively, while the projection heads have a learning rate of 1e-4.
Unless otherwise stated, we use the COCO dataset for our experiments.

As for the ADVANCE dataset, we use the Dirichlet distribution with the concentration parameter β=0.5𝛽0.5\beta=0.5 to split the data among clients based on the class labels.
The batch size is set to 16.
For LW-FedMML and Prog-FedMML, the learning rates are set according to Table III.
For FedMML, the learning rates for the image and audio encoders are set to 1e-7 and 1e-5, respectively.
The projection heads and the prediction heads have a base learning rate of 1e-4 for all approaches.
The learning rate is linearly scaled as base learning rate×batch size/256base learning ratebatch size256\text{base learning rate}\times\text{batch size}/\textit{256} [40, 41].

S4.T4.caption: TABLE IV: Comparison between FedMML (end-to-end), Prog-FedMML (progressive), and LW-FedMML (layer-wise) for text-to-image and image-to-text retrieval tasks on the COCO dataset. We also compare the relative resource requirements of each approach for a client.
S4.T4.table:
Resource Requirements Text-to-Image Image-to-Text
Memory FLOPs Comm. R@1 R@5 R@10 R@50 R@1 R@5 R@10 R@50
FedMML 1.00×\times 1.00×\times 1.00×\times 26.31 55.06 67.91 91.58 37.48 66.00 78.12 94.52
Prog-FedMML 0.95×\times 0.59×\times 0.82×\times 27.42 56.14 69.38 92.77 39.02 68.32 79.10 95.54
LW-FedMML 0.37×\times 0.42×\times 0.43×\times 25.22 53.82 66.92 91.30 35.52 65.78 76.88 94.20
references:
In Table IV, we compare the performance of different approaches and the relative resource requirements for a single client.
We measure the maximum memory required during training, while FLOPs and communication costs are measured in total across all local training epochs and FL rounds.
For FLOPs calculation, we follow the same strategy as in [32], accounting for only one input sample rather than the entire batch.
As the number of samples increases, the FLOPs would increase drastically.
Table IV demonstrates that LW-FedMML achieves comparable performance to end-to-end FedMML, with a minor drop of ≈1%absentpercent1\approx 1\% in average recall for text-to-image and image-to-text retrieval tasks, while significantly reducing resource requirements.
Specifically, LW-FedMML shows a 2.7×2.7\times reduction in memory usage, a 2.4×2.4\times decrease in FLOPs requirements, and 2.3×2.3\times lower communication costs.
Prog-FedMML achieves the best performance, surpassing end-to-end FedMML, which aligns with findings from prior studies [31, 32].
However, the resource requirements of Prog-FedMML are significantly higher than those of LW-FedMML, closely matching those of end-to-end FedMML in terms of memory and communication costs.
This could present similar challenges for Prog-FedMML as those faced by end-to-end FedMML, where many clients may fail to meet the resource requirements for participation, thereby preventing their data from being used in model training.
Fig. 6 plots the memory usage, FLOPs, and communication costs during the training process for a client.
Across all metrics, LW-FedMML consistently shows significantly lower resource requirements compared to FedMML.
In contrast, resource demands for Prog-FedMML gradually increase throughout the training, eventually matching those of FedMML.

references:
Due to the resource-constrained nature of FL clients, not all clients may be eligible to perform end-to-end or progressive training, which have high resource demands.
This means that only a subset out of all available clients can contribute to FedMML and Prog-FedMML.
Consequently, the valuable data on these low-resource clients cannot be used, adversely affecting overall performance.
Table V compares this scenario, showing that as the number of clients eligible for training decreases, the performance of FedMML and Prog-FedMML also declines.
In contrast, LW-FedMML, with its lower resource requirements, has the potential to allow these clients to participate in the training.
This inclusion enables the use of data from low-resource devices, thereby improving the overall effectiveness of the training process.

Table VI compares the performance of different approaches and relative resource requirements for a single client.
The measurement of resource requirements follows the same approach as in the instance discrimination-based setting.
The table shows that Prog-FedMML achieves the best performance, while LW-FedMML maintains competitive performance across various metrics compared to FedMML in a supervised multimodal learning setting.
In Fig. 9, we can observe that LW-FedMML significantly lowers the resource requirements compared to FedMML, while Prog-FedMML exhibits similar resource demands as FedMML.

β=50𝛽50\beta=50 β=5𝛽5\beta=5 β=0.5𝛽0.5\beta=0.5 β=0.05𝛽0.05\beta=0.05

FedMML 99.92 95.07 97.32 99.92 95.07 97.32 99.82 94.49 96.93 96.70 74.17 81.76
Prog-FedMML 100.00 96.49 98.13 100.00 96.43 98.11 100.00 95.76 97.75 95.31 76.17 82.80
LW-FedMML 100.00 95.42 97.54 99.92 95.41 97.49 99.90 95.17 97.36 96.60 74.51 81.36
references:
Data heterogeneity is one of the main challenges in FL [20].
Variations in device usage patterns, geographical locations, and other factors influence the data distribution among clients.
To control the strength of data heterogeneity within the clients’ local datasets, we adjust the β𝛽\beta parameter in the Dirichlet distribution.
A smaller β𝛽\beta value corresponds to a higher level of data heterogeneity, and vice versa.
Fig. 10 illustrates the data distribution among clients with different β𝛽\beta values for the ADVANCE dataset, and Table VII shows their results.
These results indicate that the performance of all approaches declines as the level of data heterogeneity increases.
Nonetheless, in each setting, Prog-FedMML achieves the best performance for most metrics, while LW-FedMML consistently maintains good performance comparable to the end-to-end FedMML.

In an FL environment with N𝑁N total clients, it is often impractical for all N𝑁N clients to simultaneously participate in every FL training round.
Therefore, at each FL round, we randomly select a subset of clients to participate in the training.
For this experiment, we fixed the total number of clients to N=40𝑁40N=40 and set the number of participating clients Npsubscript𝑁pN_{\text{p}} to be 10, 20, and 30, while using the ADVANCE dataset.
The total number of FL communication rounds R𝑅R is set to 120.
For both LW-FedMML and Prog-FedMML, we allocate the FL rounds for each stage Rssubscript𝑅𝑠R_{s} as [0,0,0,20,30,70]000203070[0,0,0,20,30,70].
The results in Table VIII demonstrate that LW-FedMML can sustain reasonable performance even when the client participation ratio is low.
Prog-FedMML achieves slightly higher precision but shows a minor drop in recall and F1 metrics compared to FedMML.
